bibl.title: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Philip Showalter Hench, January 11, 1955

div1.p: Lambert finds fault with the movie Yellow Jack, and criticizes Carroll and Agramonte while praising Ames.

div1.head: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Philip Showalter Hench, January 11, 1955
div1.opener:
Hazelcrest Jan 11- 55
Dr Philip Hench
Dear Sir
div1.p:
Thanks for adviceing me about the yellow jack, I
saw it, and did not think very much of it, because
one of the most important men in the work was not
even mentioned. Sidney Howard had Dr Ames in
the play. Howard made one mistake when picking
heroes for the play, he should have taken the first mos-
quito case and the first blood which would have been
Dean and Jernegan. When Dr Ames inoculated Jernegan
I helped in a small way after he drew blood from Martinez
he told me to take some cotton and alcohol and clean
a spot under left shoulder I don't know if he thought I
rubbed to hard or to long but he said a little gruffly I did
not tell you to take the hide off I only told you to clean
a spot. Perhaps the Dr. was a little nervous if the man had
died, couldn't he have been blaimed for murder? If as
it has been stated he was just the physician but I think
Dr Ames did more for experiment then either Dr Carroll
or Agramonte. Dr Carroll looked for the microb on two
different occations but failed, Agramonte did the same
at no1. Dr Ames was the only one who fed mosquitos
in the hospital Dr Carroll tried once but quit when
the spaniard kicked him off the bed. In Dr Brumbys book
there in a letter written by Moran in 1907 wherein he says
(to Dr Ames) “you were the only one who spoke to me
“about taking part in experiment” so he did not volunteer
to Maj. Reed, and did not get the salute given in the play.
I have a sworn affidavit from Hanberry wherein he states
that Dr Ames induced him and sontag to take experiment
and inoculated them. Not a physicians work. I think Ames
got all the men to volunteer except Andrus and the
spaniards. If Maj. Reed had tried to start experiment
at Las Animas at time described on page 236 in book
C2
B7
Walter Reed and yellow fever, or at Pinar del Rio
page 94 Gen. Trubys book, “no doubt Tate have given you
a better picture of what happened there” I wonder how many
men would have volunteered as human guinea pigs. When
we started yellow fever hospital at quemados, the men in
their barracks could look down and see ambulance deliver
patients but they never saw one delivered at the death house
which was only 150 feet from their quarters, and they no doubt
thought that yellow fever could not be very bad if Dr Ames took
care of the patients. The play showed Maj Gorgas attending
the patients which he did not do even Maj Reed never gave
any advice in the treatment to the boys he left that to Dr Ames
when Andrus was so sick Maj. Reed saw him and heard his
groans and cries of pain but made no recommendations
how to relieve him but wrote Surg Gen, If this man should
die I never will forgive myself for taking up this work
“Page 176 Gen Trubys book” at that time I broke quarantine
and carried Ames down to take care of Andrus, I hope
providence will punish whoever it is that have been
the cause of robbing Dr Ames of the credit due him!
I read article in Army medical journal I liked it especially the
part where she wrote some persons had claimed credit for
things they did not do. Agramonte says in his little book that
Maj Reed asked to take over the mosquitos when Lazear died, that
was false the morning Lazear was burried Dr Ames come
down to hospital and said yellow fever commission has been
broken up Maj. Reed is in Washington Lazear is dead Carroll is
sick and this morning Agramonte took his suit case and went
to New York. In Havana I visited Mr Frank Finlay I mentioned
Agramontes name, Finlay just said The Fraud he then told me
that Agramonte had made application for, or had intimated
that he was entitled to the noble price. For what? I have a
letter from Gen Truby stating that Agramonte was of very little
help to Maj Reed. I think he showed himself a heel when he
did not even attend Dr Lazears funeral. Carroll claimed cre-
dit that did not belong to him when he wrote the pamplet
treatment of yellow fever, he only added champagne and appol-
linaris which we did not have Dr Ames had learned his
treatment through years of practice but Carroll called it his.
C2
B7
If he had finished by stating, “This was the treatment
used by Dr Ames he would have told the truth
when Hanberry sent me the inclosed clipping he asked who was this
guy? And what did you do with all the champagne we were supposed
to have? Mazzuai was detailed to pinch hit for Dr Ames when he
was sick, but he came down only 4 times during the 7 days Ames
were gone, and then stood outside the door asking, how is patient?
I have in my scrap book three clippings where persons claim they
nursed Maj. Reeds patients. When visiting Memphis at one
time the niece of Lena Warner gave me copy of a speech
given by Lena before a school, in it she claimed some very
ridiculous things, had orderly (Farbes) when Lazear took sick she
gathered up all books and papers and gave them to Maj. Reed
next day but the most astounding thing of all she nursed
97 cases of yellow fever for Maj. Reed. Yes Mrs Standler were
right some persons have claimed credits to which they had
no claim I have a letter from Gen. Truby wherein he states
that Ames used Lena very little after Lazears death. She did
nurse Cartwright but he died. I thought of sending speech
to Gen Truby but Tate had written me about the Gen having
a stroke and was ill I did not want to agrivate him by
reading the lies
div1.closer:
Respectfully Gust E Lambert 17092-Lincoln Str
Hazelcrest Ill
Phone (now) Harvey 7464
P.S.
I went to Hines Hospital and had cataract removed
I can now see good. If I could only get some relieve
for my arthritis I would be as good as new Doctor please
tell me if the baths at Hot spring will benefit a man after
he have passed 80 and, if it is true that only officers can get
into the government hospital now. I thank you for the informa-
tion
Lambert
Clipping from New Orleans paper
